title: An Inter-disciplinary Inquiry into the Nature of Resilience in Teachers: Retention and Effectiveness in Times of Change
abstractText:
The series of four seminars brought together scholar practitioners from higher education, schools, social work, occupational health, local authorities and national policy organisations, to examine research evidence on policies and practices which aim to connect teacher resilience with commitment, retention, well-being and effectiveness.

The series enabled the sharing of research, policy and practice-informed perspectives between researchers in organisational and cultural psychology, education, sociology and occupational health; teacher-practitioners, and government and policy organisations which have responsibilities for teacher retention, well-being and effectiveness. It has built evidence-informed knowledge about the nature of resilience in teachers’ different life and work contexts. In particular, it has pointed to the importance of environmental effects on teachers’ resilience and the role of teacher networks and school leadership practices in sustaining the resilience that enables effective teaching. 

The series has developed a socio-culturally-oriented theoretical and methodological framework, which moves beyond seeing resilience as a personal attribute of individual teachers, and which will inform research into teachers’ well-being, professional development and effectiveness. 

The outcomes of the series have been turned into outputs which will be of relevance to teachers, school leaders, teacher educators, policy makers and all stakeholders engaged in improving the quality of education.
findingsText:
Teaching is emotionally demanding work, and levels of work-related stress, anxiety and depression are higher within education than within many other occupational groups.

Rather than focussing on managing stress, however, we argue that a more productive approach would be to focus on fostering resilience.

Resilience is not simply an individual trait, but a capacity that arises through interactions between people within organisational contexts.

Teachers' resilience can therefore be nurtured at various career stages through initial training, continuing professional development and support networks.

Most crucially, school leadership has much to contribute to the development of individual and collective resilience. Findings can be used in Professional Development programmes, for teachers and head teachers. Communities and Social Services/Policy,Education,Healthcare
